Project Description  The project will expand the production capacity of an integrated 
cement facility from 2,616 tons of clinker per day to 4,000 tons per 
day and replace the existing four wet-type kilns with one modern 
dry-type kiln, raising the annual production of cement from 1.3 
million tons per annum (TPA) to 1.7 million TPA. The more efficient 
dry kiln will reduce specific fuel consumption per unit of clinker 
produced. The project also includes reopening a limestone quarry 
and upgrading the cement mills, storage facilities, and associated 
production infrastructure.  
   
Impact,  Outcome,  and  The  project  outcome  will  be  an  expanded  and  more  efficient 
Benefits  domestic  cement  supply  indicated  by  reduced  per-unit  fuel 
consumption, increased domestic cement supply from 1.3 million 
TPA to 1.7 million TPA, the creation of jobs during construction, 
and upgrading of skills for operating staff. The impact of the project 
will be increased foreign direct investment in the private sector 
economy in Azerbaijan outside of the dominant oil and gas sector.  
   
Borrower/Project  Garadagh Cement Open Joint Stock Company, majority owned by 
Sponsor(s)  Holcim Limited

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to Garadagh Cement Open Joint Stock Company for the Garadagh Cement Expansion and 
Energy Efficiency Project. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  BACKGROUND AND RATIONALE 
A.  Project Identification and Selection 
2.  Through discussions with Holcim Limited (the parent company of the sponsor), the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  identified  the  project.  In  2008,  the  European  Bank  for 
Reconstruction and Development (EBRD), a minority shareholder in Garadagh Cement, was 
mandated as senior debt arranger.  EBRD approached ADB for the remaining parallel senior 
tranche. 
  
3.  There are limited private sector investment opportunities in Azerbaijan outside of the 
oil and gas sector, and the project represents the first opportunity for ADB to provide direct 
assistance  to  Azerbaijan's  private  sector  economy  in  an  industry  that  directly  supports 
infrastructure development. ADB's participation in this project will complement the EBRD's 
assistance and catalyze more private sector investment in Azerbaijan's infrastructure sector 
by  highlighting  attractive  investments  outside of  the  oil  and gas sector.  A  private  sector 
solution to cement supply is ideal since consumer prices are driven by production costs, and 
private  enterprises,  which  compete for market  share  by  reducing  costs,  can  expand  the 
market supply. 
 
B.  Sector Background 
4.  Between 2005 and 2008, Azerbaijan's economy was one of the fastest growing in the 
world, with gross domestic product (GDP) growth estimated at 10.8%.1 Net exports, primarily oil 
and gas, are the major drivers of growth; however, inward investment contributed a significant 
19% of GDP in 2008. Signs of economic recovery have emerged, with a per annum GDP 
growth rate in 2009 of an impressive 9.3%, a much stronger result than Azerbaijan's peers in 
the region. GDP growth of 7.4% is expected in 2010.2 This performance reflects a recovery in oil 
prices  and  improved  global  economic  output.  Despite  some  recent  cuts,  overall  budget 
expenditures—in particular for infrastructure and social spending—have increased as a result of 
the Government of Azerbaijan's crisis response, resulting in an estimated budget deficit of 2% in 
the first half of 2009.3 
 
5.  This investment growth was led by construction, which expanded by 36% during 2009, 
mostly through increases in secondary-town and rural infrastructure, residential and commercial 
building construction, and transportation infrastructure. Although the government intends to 
reduce investment spending in the medium term, the 2009 budget moderately increased capital 
investment in roads, urban infrastructure, water supply, and sanitation. This public investment 
will  become  the  single-largest  source  of  GDP  growth,  accounting  for  about  60%  of  total 
investments (footnote 2). Though the domestic economy is growing strongly, overall reliance on

2  Standard & Poor's. 2010. Azerbaijan (Republic of). London (March). 
3  EBRD. 2009. Transition Report, 2009. London.

2   
 
imports grew at 19.4% in 2008, led by increased public spending for infrastructure refurbishment 
requiring substantial imports of machinery, equipment, and construction materials.  
 
6.  Emphasis on infrastructure refurbishment and general construction has fuelled strong 
growth in cement consumption, averaging a 15% compounded annual growth rate from 2004 to 
2008.4 Azerbaijan's recent boom in oil and gas exports has driven substantial investment in 
public  and  private  sector  construction,  which  had  been  neglected  during  many  years  of 
underinvestment.  The  main  drivers  for  cement  consumption  include  ongoing  demand  for 
residential and commercial construction, which lags far behind eastern Europe and the Russian 
Federation in terms of interior area per occupant, and increased government spending for 
infrastructure, which is expected to increase to 35% of total domestic construction spending by 
2011 (footnote 3). However, due to the global crisis, there was a reduction in demand in late 
2008 and 2009, which affected near-term growth assumptions and demand. Several public and 
private projects in the planning and development phase may have been put on hold, but 
construction on those projects already under way continued.  
 
7.  In 2008, domestic cement consumption in Azerbaijan was 3.2 million tons, representing 
374 kilograms (kg) per capita. This compares similarly with per capita consumption in Eastern 
Europe but is considerably less than in other countries in the region undergoing significant 
construction and infrastructure rehabilitation, such as Kazakhstan (608 kg per capita), Iran (475 
kg per capita), and the Russian Federation (420 kg per capita). The total installed cement 
capacity in Azerbaijan, consisting of a cement plant and grinding stations, left a supply deficit of 
1.27 million tons in 2008, increasing the country's dependence on imports. Based on GDP per 
capita growth trends, cement consumption is expected to grow by 5.8% per year up to 2012, 
leading to a consumption rate of 505 kg per capita (footnote 2), a rate more in line with 
benchmarks  in  similar  countries.  Appendix  4  contains  a  more  thorough  description  of  the 
cement industry and the key drivers. 
 
C.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations  
1.  Consistency with Strategy 2020 
8.  The  project  is  consistent  with  the  private  sector  development  objectives  of  ADB’s 
Strategy  2020.5 This  financing  supports  the  expansion  and  energy  efficiency  upgrading  of 
Azerbaijan's  first  privatized  integrated  cement  manufacturer.  It  promotes  environmentally 
sustainable growth by facilitating the transfer of modern technology to a developing member 
country, improving production capacity, and reducing environmental impacts such as carbon 
emission  intensity,  particulate  matter  and  nitrous  oxides  (NO )  emissions,  and  wastewater 
x
discharge. The  project's  energy  efficiency  improvements  also  contribute  to  environmentally 
sustainable growth to arrest climate change in the region. ADB is working with the EBRD on this 
private  sector  transaction,  broadening  its  partnerships  with  key  development  agencies  in 
developing  member  countries  beyond  the  official  development  assistance  window.  This  is 
consistent with two of the drivers of change—private sector operations and partnerships—as 
described in Strategy 2020 for ADB to be a better and more active development partner.

2.  Consistency with the Country Strategy 
9.  The project is consistent with ADB’s country strategy and program (CSP) for Azerbaijan 
(last updated in 2006), which emphasizes promoting economic growth outside of the oil and gas 
sector.6 The project, through its supply of crucial cement products to large local contractors 
(mainly in transportation, commercial development, and urban development) also supports the 
CSP's emphasis on strengthening the transport and urban development sectors. The CSP also 
aims to achieve close cooperation with the EBRD in Azerbaijan. Once approved, this will be 
ADB's first nonsovereign infrastructure financing in Azerbaijan. 
 
3.  Consistency with the Energy Policy 
10.  The  project  is  consistent  with  ADB’s  Energy  Policy,7 which  advocates  technology 
transfer in energy efficiency projects, thus consistent with Holcim's role as both foreign direct 
investor and technology enabler. Through this transfer of modern dry kiln technology, the project 
serves as a demonstration project for the Caucasus and Central Asia and contributes to a 
reduction  in  fuel  consumption  per  ton  of  cement  produced.  However,  because  of  the 
government's new domestic natural gas pricing policy,8 Garadagh Cement is likely to eventually 
switch (or dual fire) from natural gas to domestic petroleum coke (petcoke) or imported coal. 
The coal ash is incorporated into the clinker, and therefore the clinker factor will remain nearly 
the same. The coal has the effect that the ash substitutes part of the clay as raw material, and 
the raw mix will be slightly adjusted to consider the coal ash. With petcoke, the ash content is 
very low and these ash effects are even smaller. The differences in energy (megajoules per ton) 
between natural gas and coal or petcoke are small. The new gas pricing regime intends to 
match the value of export demand with the country's abundant natural gas supply. The project 
also employs state-of-the-art baghouse filtration and low NO  burners to substantially reduce air 
x
emissions  and  effluent  discharge  below  current  levels  and  achieve  compliance  with  the 
European  Union,  the  World  Bank,  and  the  International  Finance  Corporation  industry 
benchmarks. 
 
III.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Project Description 
1.  The Borrower and Sponsor 
11.  The  borrower,  Garadagh  Cement  is  majority  owned  by  Holcim  Limited,  the  world's 
largest  suppliers  of  cement  and  aggregates,  based  in  Zurich,  Switzerland  (Appendix  3).9 
Garadagh Cement operates the only integrated clinker and grinding cement plant in Azerbaijan 
with cement sales of 1.15 million tons in 2009. The remainder of the market share is held by 
local grinding stations (using imported clinker mainly from Georgia and Turkey) and by cement 
imports from Georgia, Iran, the Russian Federation, Turkey, and other Central Asian countries. 
The project will increase clinker capacity from 2,616 tons per day (TPD) to 4,000 TPD, replace

the existing four wet-type kilns with one new modern dry-type kiln, and raise annual production 
of cement from 1.3 million tons per annum (TPA) to 1.7 million TPA. At the same time, the more 
energy efficient dry kiln will reduce the specific fuel consumption. 
 
12.  In addition to being the only integrated clinker-to-cement producer, Garadagh Cement 
has unique advantages over domestic competitors in that it owns substantial reserves of raw 
materials. Garadagh Cement has secured access to three sources of limestone, one of the key 
raw materials for clinker production. The first source is limestone waste from an adjacent stone 
cutting operation, which currently supplies the majority of Garadagh Cement's limestoneThe 
second source is extracting limestone at the currently dormant Shakhgaya-West quarry, owned 
by Garadagh Cement. The scope of the project includes recommissioning this quarry and 
transporting  limestone  to  the  cement  plant  by  rehabilitating  an  existing  15-kilometer  (km) 
dedicated rail line. The third source is to develop another quarry owned by Garadagh Cement at 
Caravan Sarai adjacent to the Shakhgaya-West quarry. Clay, the other key raw material for 
clinker production, is sourced from a clay and shale and owned by Garadagh Cement.  
  
13.  Competitive  benchmarking  conducted  by  AC  Nielsen  in  2008  found  that  Garadagh 
Cement  has  100%  brand  awareness  in  its  geographical  markets  and  a  marketing 
effectiveness10 in the Baku region of 94%, compared with 20%–60% for its top four competitors. 
Sales  staff  are  trained  through  four  modules  each  year  on  selling  the  right  cement  (and 
strength) for the right application to customers and substantiating Garadagh Cement's price 
premium. The company holds technical seminars for contractors on the benefit of its sulfate-
resistant cement, which is ideal to combat the aggressive climatic conditions that result from the 
high salinity of the Caspian Sea. More details on the sponsor can be found in Appendix 3, and 
on Garadagh Cement in Appendix 4. 
 
2.  Project Design 
14.  The project scope consists of a new five-stage precalciner preheater, a rotary dry kiln 
with modern grate cooler, a vertical roller mill, upgrades to three cement mills, reopening of a 
nearby limestone quarry, and new cement storage facilities and associated plant infrastructure 
(Table 1). The cement mills are relatively simple ball mill devices consisting of a steel vessel, 
steel mill balls, and electric motor drives; with regular maintenance and periodic efficiency 
improvements they can be operated over the long-term. The kiln system of the project will be 
constructed by CBMI Construction Company (CBMI) under a fixed-price turnkey engineering, 
procurement, and construction (EPC) contract which was awarded through competitive bidding. 
A number of key components will be supplied by European suppliers with interfacing facilitated 
by the Holcim Group Services (HGRS) team based in Switzerland. Project scope outside of the 
kiln system, including the dedicated rail line rehabilitation, quarry crusher facilities, cement mill 
upgrades, and office building upgrades, are contracted directly by Garadagh Cement to local 
contractors.

15.  The  total  cost  of  the  project  including  contingencies  is  €325  million  ($442  million 
equivalent), of which the sponsor is contributing 57%, or €185 million ($251 million equivalent), 
as equity, sourced mostly by cash flow from operations and subordinated debt from Holcim.  
 
16.  The project provides substantial energy efficiency gains by switching clinker production 
from wet to dry process and reducing fuel consumption. However, electricity consumption will 
slightly increase by replacing the wet process slurry preparation with raw materials grinding, 
which requires more electrical energy. Overall average electricity consumption will increase by 
19% from 61.2 kWh per ton of clinker to 72.8 kWh, and will be supplied by a new 80,000 
kilovolt-ampere (kVA) substation installed and commissioned by Garadagh Cement in 2009 to 
step down power from the 11 kilovolt (kV) utility distribution line to the dry kiln and existing 4,160 
kV cement plant circuit.  
 
17.  In accordance with Holcim corporate environmental objectives, the project has been 
designed to also be able to use alternative fuel resources to fire the kiln.  
 
3.  Project Outputs and Outcome 
18.  The project outputs will be 4,000 tons per day (1.24 million TPA) of clinker production by 
the end of the second quarter of 2011, yielding 1.7 millions TPA of cement, and a decrease in 
specific fuel consumption per unit of clinker produced. The expansion, upgrade, and operation 
of the project will be in compliance with ADB and EBRD environmental and social safeguards. 
 
19.  The project outcome will be an expanded and more efficient domestic cement supply 
indicated by reduced per-unit fuel consumption, increased domestic cement supply from 1.3 
million TPA to 1.7 million TPA, the creation of jobs during construction, and upgrading of skills 
for operating staff. Beyond the stated outcome, the project will also demonstrate that Azerbaijan 
is conducive to foreign direct investment and privatization of major state-owned enterprises 
outside of the oil and gas sector.

B.  Development Impact 
1.  Contribution to Economic Growth and Poverty Reduction 
20.  The project will achieve significant energy savings through the use of sustainable and 
environmentally friendly dry kiln technology, resulting in a reduction in energy use per unit of 
clinker produced. Dry kiln technology will be transferred from a developed economy and the 
skills of local operations staff will be upgraded so they are trained to operate a state-of-the-art 
production  facility.  Supply  of  high-quality  indigenous  cement  will  support  the  government's 
investments  in  infrastructure  (specifically  roads,  bridges,  ports,  and  water  supply).  The 
government has indicated capital expenditure plans of $3.7 billion for infrastructure projects in 
2010. Many of these projects are intended to support agribusiness, trade, tourism, and regional 
integration so that the economy diversifies its sources of growth outside of the oil and gas 
sector. 
 
2.  Private Sector Development 
21.  The  assistance  of  ADB  and  the  EBRD  facilitates  foreign  direct  investment  by  an 
international  sponsor  with  the  highest  corporate  governance  standards,  and  the  project 
promotes private sector participation outside of the country's dominant oil and gas sector. The 
project  ensures  a  sustainable  local  supply  of  high-quality  cement,  which  will  support  the 
government's investments in the transport, water, and urban infrastructure sectors and other 
commercial development, including tourism.  
 
22.  The  assistance  is  aligned  with  the private  sector  development goals of  one  of the 
company's  shareholders,  Azerbaijan  Investment  Company,  which  is  mandated  by  the 
Azerbaijan Ministry of Economic Development to develop the private sector outside of the oil 
and gas sector in order to enhance the country's long-term sustainability. This diversification is 
critical to promoting inclusive growth and reducing poverty in Azerbaijan. 
 
C.  Environment and Social Dimensions 
1.  Environment 
23.  ADB has classified the project as environmental category A, and the borrower has 
conducted a full environmental and social impact assessment (ESIA). The ESIA was posted on 
the company's website11 on 19 November 2008 and the full document was reposted on ADB's 
website on 19 December 2009 as per the requirements of ADB's Safeguard Policy Statement.12 
Hard copies in Azeri were supplied to the settlements of Sahil and Umid and the EBRD resident 
office in Baku. A local consulting company prepared an environmental impact assessment for 
application  to  the  Azerbaijan  Ministry  of  Energy  and  Natural  Resources  for  environmental 
approval.  
 
24.  The ESIA report contains detailed findings of likely environmental and social impacts 
associated with the operation and maintenance of the project. The ESIA has established an 
environmental and social management plan (ESMP), setting forth avoidance and mitigation 
measures and monitoring for identified impacts. Despite a substantial increase in production 
capacity, and the likely switch from gas to coal, the project will have a reduced net air impact

kiln process. Though the project is switching to a more carbon-intensive fuel for economic 
reasons, carbon emissions are being reduced through energy efficiency and reduced clinker 
factor (using fly ash from coal combustion in cement, which reduces the proportion of clinker in 
the final cement product) as compared to operation of the four wet kilns for the same production 
capacity. NO  emissions are less than 500 milligrams (mg) per ton. The wet kilns will be 
x
decommissioned no later than 2 years from commercial operation of the dry kiln.13  
 
26.  The existing wet kiln process uses a substantial amount of water (600,000 cubic meters 
[m3] per year) for production. The dry kiln will consume 65% less water compared to the existing 
operation. While the present operation uses treated wastewater, the use of fresh water from the 
main pipeline will be necessary. However, a water-saving, closed water cycle is planned for 
production. The wastewater discharge will be reduced by about 56% compared to the present 
operation.  Effluent  from  the  project  will  be  treated  at  a  new  on-site  treatment  plant  to 
international  effluent  standards.  Further  details  on  environmental  impacts  and  mitigation 
measures are described in the ESIA in Supplementary Appendix A. 
 
27.  In 2003, the company implemented an environmental management system according to 
ISO 14001 in parallel with the ISO 9001 quality management system. The company has a unit 
for operational health and safety and environmental and security issues. The plant runs an 
established occupational health and safety management system in line with Holcim's corporate 
policy.  Clear  organizational  accountabilities  are  supporting  by  a  program  of  training, 
communication, strict procedural discipline, and locally developed policies and action plans. 
 
28.  The existing occupational health and safety system will be transferred to the operation of 
kiln 6, including the quarry activities. In addition, the project will implement an ESMP which 
includes management and monitoring activities to address issues and mitigate impacts. Overall 
responsibility for the implementation of the ESMP lies with Garadagh Cement for all project 
phases, including compliance by all contractors. Special awareness training will be provided for 
employees  working  with  new  or  modified  equipment  relating  to  the  dry  kiln.  Semiannual 
monitoring reports will be submitted to the senior lenders during construction in line with ADB's 
requirements, and annual reports will be submitted thereafter (including details on greenhouse 
gas emissions). The reports shall cover all aspects of environmental, health, and safety-related 
aspects such as permits, status of compliance with obligations, and any corrective measures 
required.

2.  Social Dimensions 
29.  As described in the ESIA, no land acquisition is required for the project, other than a few 
discontinuous parcels of government land adjacent to the plant boundary wall.14 The new dry 
kiln will be built within the Garadagh Cement plant premises (approximately 52 hectares) and all 
land is owned by Garadagh Cement. Due to the arid conditions, there is no notable agricultural 
use, except small-scale herding of goats and sheep. The reopening of the Shakhgaya-West 
limestone quarry results in no land use impacts since the area comprises arid land, which is 
neither under permanent nor temporary use. The rail and road infrastructure to be rehabilitated 
remain in the same alignment and also require no additional land. There are two settlements 
within the vicinity of the cement plant: Sahil and Umid. Sahil settlement (population 22,700) was 
established originally as a workers’ settlement for the cement plant during the Soviet period. It 
has grown into a highly industrial and commercial town, and the proportion of Garadagh Cement 
employees in the total population of Sahil is relatively low. Umid settlement (population 2,000) is 
comprised mainly (75%) of internally displaced persons from the Nagorno–Karabagh conflict. 
The Umid population has expressed its expectation for project-related employment opportunities 
(more than 60% of the peak construction workforce of 700–900 persons will be locally hired). 
Garadagh Cement has indicated it will facilitate this by promptly communicating employment 
opportunities to Sahil, Umid, and the region.  
 
30.  Based on the findings of the ESIA, and verified by ADB during transaction review, the 
project is classified C in respect of ADB's involuntary resettlement and indigenous peoples 
policies. In June 2008, public meetings were held in the villages of Sahil and Umid where 
attendees expressed enthusiasm for energy efficiency upgrades but expressed concern about 
future airborne pollution due to the increase in production capacity and the fuel switch from 
natural gas to coal.15 Garadagh Cement has an established public consultation and disclosure 
plan and has made project documents and grievance forms available to stakeholders and the 
public (footnote 12). On 17–18 December 2008, further consultation was carried out on the draft 
final ESIA, with project staff available to directly answer questions and provide additional project 
literature (ESIA, project pamphlet, posters with simulated pictures of the expansion, and results 
of  dispersion  calculations)  and  no  additional  major  issues  were  raised  by  the  public  and 
stakeholders.  Garadagh  Cement  will  nominate  a  community  liaison  officer  responsible  for 
continuing  communications  with  the  public  during  construction  and  operation.  Garadagh 
Cement will also implement a grievance mechanism where the community liaison officer will be 
responsible for recording and responding to grievances.

I.  POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A. Link to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy 
 
1.  Based on the country poverty assessment, the country partnership strategy, and the sector analysis, describe how the 
project would directly or indirectly contribute to poverty reduction and how it is linked to the poverty reduction strategy of the 
partner country. 
 
The project is consistent with the Asian Development Bank’s country strategy and program (CSP) for Azerbaijan (last updated 
in 2006), which emphasizes promoting economic growth in industries and sectors outside of the oil and gas sector.a Cement 
is a critical product needed by large local contractors working on various transport and urban development infrastructure 
projects being prioritized by the Government of Azerbaijan. These infrastructure projects are key to the diversification of 
economic growth of the country; hence, by supporting a project in the building materials sector, the project can indirectly 
contribute to poverty reduction. 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                 Targeting Classification: General intervention  
 
1. Key issues. By locally producing cement which is cost-effective for local industries, the project is expected to sustain 
infrastructure development for roads, urban transport, and tourism and help strengthen private sector activities in associated 
industries in the country through employment generation and the promotion of related businesses. Garadagh Cement has 
more than 580 employees, of whom around 470 are directly involved in cement production. A large percentage of Garadagh 
Cement's employees are from two settlements within the vicinity of the cement plant and the quarries. Expansion of the 
cement plant will sustain jobs and opportunities for the local people in these two settlements. In addition to direct employment, 
the construction phase of the project will contribute to poverty reduction by boosting the local economy and Azeri enterprises. 
During construction, the project will offer a wide range of opportunities with regard to the delivery of services, such as catering 
and accommodation for the construction workforce or the delivery of subcontractor services and goods for the construction 
works. The potential for local procurement of works, goods, and services, either directly via Garadagh Cement or the 
engineering, procurement, and construction (EPC) contractor, is presently estimated to be in the range of €50 million to €80 
million. Garadagh Cement plans to hold an information event for interested local companies about business opportunities in 
relation to the project. This will be undertaken in coordination with the Ministry of Economic Development and the Baku 
Chamber of Commerce and local entrepreneur organizations. 
 
2. Design features. The project will assist Garadagh Cement to modernize its Garadagh cement production plant which is 
located near Sahil Settlement about 34 kilometers (km) southwest of Baku and about 1 km inland from the Caspian Sea. 
Within the frame of plant modernization, a state-of-the-art dry-process rotary kiln including raw material handling and raw 
material preparation will be constructed at the Garadagh Cement plant site. This new dry kiln 6 will replace the present four 
wet-process kilns which will be decommissioned no later than 2 years after commercial operation of kiln 6. The project scope 
also consists of a new five-stage precalcsiner preheater, a vertical roller mill, upgrades to three cement mills, the reopening of 
a nearby limestone quarry, and new storage facilities and plant infrastructure.

II.  SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A.  Findings of Social Analysis  
 
Key issues. The environmental and social impact assessment undertaken for the project has identified the following social 
and socioeconomic impacts. 
 
Land acquisition and involuntary resettlement. All land necessary for the project is owned by Garadagh Cement. The new 
kiln and associated facilities will be built within the existing premises. The reopening of the Shakhgaya-West limestone quarry

16     Appendix 2 
results in no land use impacts. There is very little agricultural production in the region due to the arid climate and poor soils. 
There is no notable agricultural use, except small-scale herding of predominantly goats and sheep. The project will not restrict 
these activities as the area is vast and uninhabited. The rehabilitation work on the railway between the plant and the quarry 
will take place along the same alignment and no additional land will be acquired. 
 
Indigenous people. There are two settlements in the vicinity of the cement plant and the quarries: Sahil and Umid. Sahil 
settlement (population 22,700) was originally established as a workers’ settlement for the cement plant during the Soviet 
period. It has grown into a highly industrial and commercial town. Umid settlement (population 2,000) comprises mainly 
internally  displaced  persons  (75%)  from  the  Nagorno–Karabagh  conflict.  There  are  no  indigenous  people  in  these 
settlements. 
 
Labor. The construction period of the project will have a temporary (about 3 years) overall positive impact on the local labor 
market as a high proportion (more than 60%) of the estimated peak construction workforce will be locally employed. The great 
majority of construction staff will be male. Information with regard to construction recruitment will be comprehensively and 
promptly communicated to the local population by Garadagh Cement and the EPC contractor. Employment opportunities will 
be announced on notice boards in the communities. The appointment of a Garadagh Cement community liaison officer will 
facilitate continuous contact with the local population and will at the same time allow Garadagh Cement and the EPC 
contractor to explore local potential workforce options effectively.  
 
About 60%–80% of the laborers for civil and structural works will be unskilled or semiskilled. It is estimated that during 
mechanical and electrical erection qualified third-country nationals will be employed on site.. The large total number of 
workers and the presence of foreign workers could potentially lead to friction, related to misconduct or cultural differences, 
among the workforce or between workers and the local population. To minimize the potential for this to happen, a work site 
regulation and a workers’ code of conduct will be set up and workers’ compliance with rules will be supervised. If on-site 
issues arise, conflicts will be managed by the official representatives of the Garadagh Cement plant who will receive training 
in advance. Garadagh Cement will appoint a community liaison officer, and establish a complaints and grievance procedure in 
order to identify conflict issues early and to facilitate their resolution together with local residents. 
 
During operations, the Garadagh Cement workforce will be working with advanced production technology. Significant 
investment will be made to increase skills of the company personnel (technical staff in particular), to ensure that they have the 
required level of proficiency. Introduction of state-of-the art technology will lead to increased productivity and, as a result, will 
lead to obsolete staff positions and eventually to staff reduction. It is mainly workers with low skill levels who will become 
redundant. A comprehensive retrenchment plan will be developed by Garadagh Cement’s human resources department to 
minimize potential negative impacts of loss of employment. Garadagh Cement will provide comprehensive assistance 
programs guided by international best practice to the employees subject to redundancy on top of what is prescribed by Azeri 
labor legislation. As the company intends to expand business further into other construction material sectors, internal transfer 
options will be considered. Outside of Garadagh Cement’s own staff, no significant employment effect will occur.

18    Appendix 3 
SPONSOR BACKGROUND 
 
A.  Company Description 
 
1.  The sponsor, Holcim Limited, is one of the world's largest suppliers of cement and 
aggregates.1 The group also supplies ready-mix concrete, concrete products, asphalt, and a 
range  of  services.  Holcim  holds  majority  and  minority  stakes  in  operations  in  around  70 
countries  and  employs  around  80,000  people.  This  broad-based  presence  helps  stabilize 
earnings by evening out cyclical fluctuations in individual markets more effectively. Revenue 
streams in 2009 from Asia and Latin America confirm that this compensatory effect operates 
well even during recessionary phases. With the acquisition of Cemex operations in Australia, 
Holcim has further expanded its geographical presence. 
 
2.  The Holcim group of companies has the lowest carbon dioxide unit emissions worldwide 
of any cement manufacturer. Holcim is one of the leading companies in sustainability worldwide 
through its environmental stewardship, human capital development, and corporate citizenship 
programs. The group has been confirmed as a member of the Dow Jones Sustainability Index in 
2009─2010 in the building materials industry and has been included in both the Dow Jones 
Sustainability Index and the Dow Jones STOXX Sustainability Index for the past 7 years. 
 
B.  Operational and Financial Performance 
 
3.  Despite  the  sharp  decline  in  demand,  especially  in  mature markets, Holcim's  2009 
financial performance remained relatively stable. The group had an operating profit of SwF2.8 
billion ($2.6 billion equivalent) on net sales of SwF21.1 billion ($19.9 billion equivalent), down 
16%  from  the  previous  year.  Operating  earnings  before  interest,  tax,  depreciation,  and 
amortization shrank by 13% to SwF4.6 billion. Financial performance was also affected by the 
continued appreciation of the Swiss franc relative to the currencies of major group companies in 
Europe, Mexico, and India. However, the group has an above-peer-average profitability and 
cash flow generation capability. In 2009, cement sales decreased by 8% to 131.9 million tons, 
and aggregate sales decreased by 14% to 143.4 million tons. Additionally, 3.5 million tons of 
other mineral components were sold in 2009. 
  
4.  Holcim is a publicly traded company listed on the SIX Swiss Exchange with shares 
traded on SWX Europe, and as of 31 December 2008 had a total market capitalization of 
SwF26.3 billion ($24.8 billion equivalent).2 The company is rated “investment grade” by the 
international rating agencies as follows: Standard & Poor’s, BBB, outlook stable; Moody's, 
Baa2, outlook stable; and Fitch Ratings, BBB, outlook stable.3 These ratings compare favorably 
with Holcim’s principal global competition in cement and aggregates: LaFarge (BBB–, negative), 
HeidelbergCement (BB–, negative), and Cemex (B, stable).4  
 
 
                                                
1  Based on volumes shipped in 2008 of 143.4 million tons. The largest supplier, Lafarge, shipped 155.0 million tons. 
2  Holcim Limited. 2010. Annual Report 2009. Jona, Switzerland. 
3  Holcim Limited. 2009. Press Release 9 July 2009. Jona, Switzerland. In January 2010, Fitch Ratings upgraded its 
outlook to “stable” from “negative” because of Holcim's relative strength over other major cement entities, coming 
as a result of its geographical diversification and high liquidity. 
4  Fitch Ratings. February 2010. Fitch Ratings: Holcim Limited. London.

Appendix 3     19 
 
C.  Holcim Auslandbeteiligungs  
 
5.  Holcim  Auslandbeteiligungs  is  an  intermediary  holding  company  incorporated  in 
Germany, which holds stakes in more than 20 Holcim group companies in Central and Eastern 
Europe (Austria, Azerbaijan, Bulgaria, Croatia, Hungary, Romania, the Russian Federation, 
Serbia, and the Slovak Republic) as well as in Iran and Cyprus.

20     Appendix 4 
COMPANY (BORROWER) BACKGROUND 
 
A.  Company Ownership 
 
1.  Prior to 1999, Garadagh Cement was a state-owned company. It was established in 
1949 under the former Soviet Union to support government construction projects in the former 
Soviet Union. Two wet kiln lines were initially installed, and between 1957 and 1964 three more 
wet kilns were installed; four are in operation today (kilns 1–4).  
 
2.  Holcim acquired 90% ownership of Garadagh Cement in the course of a competitive 
tender for privatization in 1999. Between that time and 2004, Holcim invested $23 million as per 
the terms of the privatization tender, and received the final privatization certificate from the 
Government  of  Azerbaijan  in  February  2007.  Holcim  presently  holds  69.6%  of  Garadagh 
Cement, having sold a 10% stake to the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development 
(EBRD)  in  2007,  and  10%  to  the  Azerbaijan  Investment  Company  (AIC),  a  government-
sponsored equity investment fund, in 2008. The AIC is the private sector investment agency of 
the Ministry of Economic Development tasked with the objective of investing and facilitating 
growth  outside  the  oil and gas  sector  while  still focusing  on  employment  and  value-chain 
creation. The remaining 10.4% of shares are owned by the company's employees.  
 
B.  Management 
 
3.  As required under the civil code in Azerbaijan, the company has a supervisory council 
which  directs  day-to-day  operations  through  the  general  director.  The  supervisory  council 
comprises three representatives from Holcim, one from the EBRD, and one from the AIC. The 
chair of the supervisory council is nominated by Holcim. The general director of Garadagh 
Cement attends all supervisory council meetings but is not a voting member. 
 
4.  While there is an on-site project manager for Garadagh Cement, Holcim Limited has 
established a steering committee which meets on a regular basis to review implementation 
progress and provide guidance on technical issues.

GLOSSARY 
 
  Clinker  –  The base component of cement, consisting of a mixture of 
limestone  and  clay  combined  by  chemical  reaction  in  the 
cement kiln stage. Final cement composition mixes clinker with 
other materials, such as gypsum and volcanic sand for desired 
physical properties and curing performance. 
       
  Portland  –  The most common type of cement in general use throughout 
cement  the world and the basic ingredient for concrete and aggregate 
products. 
       
  ready mix  –  Final  concrete  product  consisting  of  Portland  cement  and 
various  aggregates  depending  on  the  performance 
requirements of the concrete application.
